rename.from: ANSI Escape Sequence Colors not working in Powershell
rename.to: ANSI Escape Sequence Colors not working in Powershell (v0.49.0 issue)

body:
Confirming that this is a regression bug in the latest version 0.49.0.

Downgrading to version 0.48.0 on Windows:
```
scoop install starship@0.48.0
```

The prompt shows up fine again:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14130413/106402431-72dba000-63f7-11eb-8a06-101814baa63c.png)
Facing same issue with 0.49. Older rel 0.48 works fine.

Same issue for me with 0.49.0. I took some time to bisect the first wrong commit:

```
5cf1c8a7bdc9cd385d37dd1310b09099a966796d is the first bad commit
commit 5cf1c8a7bdc9cd385d37dd1310b09099a966796d
Author: Thomas O'Donnell <andytom@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Thu Jan 21 22:59:14 2021 +0100

    perf(utils): Add timeout to `utils::exec_cmd` (#2171)

    * perf(utils): Add timeout to `utils::exec_cmd`

    This adds a timeout to any command executed using the `utils::exec_cmd`.
    The initial time limit is hard coded to 500ms but if required we can
    make this configurable. Have also switched the tests to be a bit more
    granular on which systems they are ignored.

    * Terminate the processes if they timeout

 Cargo.lock   | 16 ++++++++++++++--
 Cargo.toml   |  1 +
 src/utils.rs | 51 ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++-------
 3 files changed, 59 insertions(+), 9 deletions(-)
```
Jupyter terminal (IPython notebook) is also affected. ConEmu is not affected.

I've just had a look at the change. It seems that the issue itself is independent of using `process_control` and the timeout, but can be triggered by simply changing `utils::internal_exec_cmd()` to use `std::process` differently.

Before the commit above the code was using [std::process::Command.output()](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/struct.Command.html#method.output) to execute the command and capture its output.

Simply changing the code to [spawn()](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/struct.Command.html#method.spawn) the process and then use the resulting `Child` object's [wait_with_output()](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/struct.Child.html#method.wait_with_output) method triggers the issue (without introducing 3rd party dependencies).

@kkovaacs I can't reproduce the issue, so can you check if adding `.stdin(Stdio::piped())` in `internal_exec_cmd` helps? https://github.com/starship/starship/blob/9e21e3cf5fb0938902c526ed3917e27d289baca8/src/utils.rs#L278

@davidkna No, it doesn't seem to help.

Based on the stdlib source it seems to me that the only difference between calling `output()` and `spawn()` is that `output()` calls the internal spawn implementation like [this](https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/std/process.rs.html#876-881):

```
spawn(imp::Stdio::MakePipe, false)
```

while `spawn()` calls it like [this](https://doc.rust-lang.org/src/std/process.rs.html#847-849):

```
spawn(imp::Stdio::Inherit, true)
```

How about if you move
```rust
#[cfg(windows)]
let _ = ansi_term::enable_ansi_support();
```
to the end of `main.rs`?

Bingo. I've put an extra `enable_ansi_support()` to the end of main and now ANSI escape sequences work properly.

It seems somehow executing commands in this particular way leads to disabling [ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/setconsolemode).
Does it also work if you remove the first `enable_ansi_support()`?

Yes, it does work when calling `enable_ansi_support()` at the end of main only. (Which seems to make sense, since this way ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING is enabled after all commands have finished.)

I suspect the root cause might be related to stdin being inherited by commands executed by starship -- and one of them maybe disabling ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING on the console?
If you think that's the cause can you check what happen if you add `.stdin(Stdio::null())` in `internal_exec_cmd`?

Ok, I've narrowed down the issue to calling `id -u` in the `modules::username::get_uid()`. This seems to be the `id.exe` installed with Git on my machine, and for some reason it seems to disable the ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING flag on the console it's running on. (Most probably this should not be run on Windows at all, since the only purpose of its result is comparing it with ROOT_UID (0), which is bogus on Windows.)

Just removing this one command seems to make a difference.

I'll test explicitly setting stdin to null right away.

issue.title: fix(windows): fix windows terminal ANSI escape sequences

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
#### Description
Release 0.49.0 broke ANSI escape sequence processing for some Windows Terminal users by making some subtle changes how commands are now executed.

#### Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #2254
Closes #2246
Closes #2252

#### Screenshots (if appropriate):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/629536/106620640-0c2ec180-6572-11eb-8191-fc0cd2574487.png)

#### How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, tests ran to see how -->
<!--- your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
- [ ] I have tested using **MacOS**
- [ ] I have tested using **Linux**
- [X] I have tested using **Windows**

#### Checklist:
<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
<!--- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [ ] I have updated the tests accordingly.

body: Yep, explicitly setting stdin to null seems to fix the issue.
